Joint tuberculosis (TB) uncommon manifestation TB typically presents subacute chronic atraumatic inflammatory symptoms single, large, weight-bearing joints.In Canada, epidemiological risk factors TB include extended time spent countries high burden TB, known exposure TB population disproportionately affected TB (e.g., people born outside Canada, Indigenous ethnicity history homelessness incarceration).Synovial thickening, joint effusions, juxta-articular osteopenia, peripheral osseous erosions gradual joint space narrowing magnetic resonance imaging computed tomography suggestive joint TB.Specialized mycobacterial culture gold standard diagnosis TB, nucleic acid amplification tests increasingly accessible allow rapid diagnosis joint TB.Treatment joint TB started promptly preservation joint function prevention irreversible destruction.A 47-year-old man presented emergency department 2 weeks acute-on-chronic pain right knee. He described 5-year history chronic pain right knee, 1 flare-up 3 years presentation, resolved weeks ibuprofen use. He previously sought care problem. He healthy, chronic medical conditions previous surgeries, tested negative HIV. He smoked crystal methamphetamine daily 10 years history intravenous drug use. He immigrated Philippines 16 years returned.When examined, patient afebrile normal vital signs. His right knee swollen limited flexion extension. He overlying erythema tenderness palpation bursa joint line. He inflamed joints. Initial laboratory results showed leukocyte count 8.4 (normal 411)  109/L elevated C-reactive protein level 34.4 (normal < 3.1) mg/L. A radiograph patients right knee showed bony destruction knee joint irregular lucency medial tibial plateau . A computed tomography (CT) scan showed cortical destruction peripheral osseous erosions juxta-articular osteopenia . The patient admitted internal medicine service initial treating physicians concerned malignant disease; ordered CT scan chest, abdomen pelvis, showed mild, biapical lung scarring .Bloody synovial fluid aspirated patients right knee joint, leukocyte count 36.7  109/L (79% neutrophils, 15% lymphocytes, 6% monomacrophages) erythrocyte count 150  109/L, crystals organisms Gram stain. Cultures mycobacteria negative acid-fast bacilli staining. Given findings, bacterial septic arthritis suspected treated empirical antibiotic therapy (intravenous  ceftriaxone 2 g daily, IV vancomycin target trough 1020 mg/L). After 6 days, patients knee improved bacterial cultures synovial fluid remained negative. The internal medicine team consulted infectious diseases team.We suspected tuberculosis (TB) based 3 factors, chronic nature monoarthritis, pulmonary apical scarring chest imaging patient emigrated Philippines  designated country high burden TB World Health Organization (WHO), fourth highest national incidence TB globally. We identified identifiable risk factors TB, previous incarceration, homelessness known close contact TB.Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) TB GeneXpert MTB/RIF Ultra assay (Cephied) performed samples synovial fluid, confirmed presence Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Smear testing sputum samples negative acid-fast bacilli. We prescribed standard weight-based dosages rifampin (10 mg/kg/d), isoniazid (5 mg/kg/d) pyridoxine (25 mg/d), pyrazinamide (25 mg/kg/d) ethambutol (15 mg/kg/d) discharged continue therapy care provincial TB program.Four weeks later, samples patients synovial fluid showed growth M. tuberculosis susceptible first-line anti-TB medications receiving. Mycobacterial cultures sputum samples negative, suggesting pulmonary TB. At follow-up 9-month course treatment, patient considerable improvement knee pain (pain extended use), periarticular lower leg swelling range motion (full flexion extension). He returned work ambulating need mobility aid. Given extensive destruction knee joint, planned refer orthopedic surgeon consideration knee arthroplasty.
